Butagumi Review | Bon Appetit

Thanks to a kitchen that operates with a level of skill and craft befitting of one of Tokyo’s best restaurants, the tonkatsu—breaded deep-fried pork cutlets—exists on a higher plane than any other in the city. The meats are luxurious and the cooking is obsessive in detail. This isn‘t a taste of what tonkatsu has been—it‘s a taste of what it‘s become.ORDER THE: pork of your choice in the thickness you deserve. While the menu is based on a rotating selection of heritage pork, meaning that each visit might present different options, you’ll always get to select how thick you want your cutlet. Most pork will have regular or deluxe options with certain types available as “extra-fatty super deluxe.“ Be on the lookout for the two-month aged pork belly tonkatsu or the Iberico pork from Spain.THE VIBE IS: quiet. Butagumi occupies an old house in the Nishi-Azabu neighborhood, and its iconic moon-shaped window on the second floor makes it easy to spot from the street. Despite its high pedigree, dinner here is a relaxed affair.PRACTICAL STUFF: Opened from Tuesday to Sunday. Lunch is between 11:30 a.m. and 2 p.m., and dinner is from 6 p.m. to 10 p.m. Closed on Mondays. The staff speaks some English and the menu is available in English as well. Reservations are recommended. The nearest subway station is Roppongi (it’s a bit of a walk from the station).Photo by Xavier Girard LachaîneLook for the moon-shaped window on the second story.
Photo by Xavier Girard LachaîneThe chefs at Butagumi are details-obsessed.
